name: eDisease
goal: Monitor aquatic diseases around the globe.
task: Log observations when you are in, on, near the ocean!
description: Diseases in the ocean have many origins. Sewage from human-based outflows, dust and bacteria carried from land (desertification), and increasing water temperatures due to our warming climate, for example, have resulted in increased prevalence of waterborne disease outbreaks, some of which have caused mass mortalities. eDisease is working to capture broad trends of marine diseases across the globe — from fish to seals and corals —  to work towards a better understanding of the movement and scale of various diseases, to promote new research questions, and support informed decisions.
search_terms: disease, parasites, tumours, marine parasites, wasting disease
how_to_join: Download the app, join the eDisease team, and start logging observations next time you are in, on, or near the ocean.
consent_statement: Terms of use regarding eOceans' mobile app and platform can be found here: https://www.eoceans.co/terms-of-use
participation_schedule: As often as you can, whenever you are near, on, or in the ocean!
data_results: The data obtained by this Team is kept within the eOceans platform and will not be given or sold to outside parties.

name: eFisheries
task: Log observations when you are in, on, near the ocean!
description: The global economic value of ocean capture fisheries is US$225 to 240 billion per year. Many fish, the prey that feed those fish, and the ecosystems that support them are  degraded. This team aims to look at broads trends fishing activity — recreational or commercial. The primary aim is to instigate new co-generated research questions, but also to better understand how threats, like climate change, change the way we fish.
search_terms: fish, fisheries, blue economy, marine life, fishers, anglers, commercial fishing
how_to_join: Download the app, join the eFisheries team, and start logging observations next time you are in, on, or near the ocean.
consent_statement: Terms of use regarding eOceans' mobile app and platform can be found here: https://www.eoceans.co/terms-of-use
participation_schedule: As often as you can, whenever you are near, on, or in the ocean!
data_results: The data obtained by this Team is kept within the eOceans platform and will not be given or sold to outside parties.

name: eBlueCarbon
goal: Monitor blue carbon ecoystems across the globe.
task: Log observations of what you see when you are in, on, or near the ocean!
description: Blue carbon ecosystems such as mangroves, tidal marshes, and seagrass meadows have an incredible ability to capture and store carbon while providing irreplaceable habitats for critical species, improving water quality, providing coastal protection, and supporting healthy fisheries. Yet these blue carbon ecosystems are being lost each year to aquaculture, mangrove forest exploitation, pollution, coastal development, and conditions driven by climate change. This team aims to capture broad trends on the health of blue carbon ecosystems on a global scale to allow for more informed decisions and questions.
search_terms: blue carbon, carbon capture, climate change, ocean, coastlines, mangroves, tidal marshes, sea grass
how_to_join: Download the app, join the eBlueCarbon team, and start logging observations next time you are in, on, or near the ocean.
consent_statement: Terms of use regarding eOceans' mobile app and platform can be found here: https://www.eoceans.co/terms-of-use
participation_schedule: As often as possible - whenever you are near, on, or in the ocean!
data_results: The data obtained by this Team is kept within the eOceans platform and will not be given or sold to outside parties.

value: Step Up To The Plate - Lunch Food Waste Audit
name: Step Up To The Plate - Lunch Food Waste Audit
goal: Assess food wasted at lunch with the goal of reducing waste in the future.
task: Measure and document the amount of food wasted during lunch.
description: In the United States, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) estimates that food reached landfills more than any other single material. When food goes to the landfill, it rots and produces methane – a greenhouse gas more potent than carbon dioxide. We could reduce roughly 6%-8% of all human-caused greenhouse gas emissions if we just stopped wasting food. Take our Lunch Food Waste Audit – it’s a two-week project that asks you to track your lunch waste and change some habits. Measure as best you can and take photos. Share your findings and share what you will do differently.
search_terms: food waste, climate crisis, climate change, lunch audit
how_to_join: Download our audit sheet or just track what you had for lunch, noting what you didn't eat and why you threw it away.
participation_schedule: Once a day during the week - at lunch.
data_results: Data will be available to anyone.

data_access.label: Bulk download of all data at once (e.g. by FTP download)

name: NASA GLOBE CLOUD GAZE
presenter: NASA and The Zooniverse Online Platform
goal: Interpret cloud photos to help scientists better understand our climate.
task: Identify cloud cover, cloud types, and other phenomena in photographs.
description: Have you wondered what happens to your sky photographs taken through GLOBE Observer: Clouds? The NASA GLOBE CLOUD GAZE, a partnership between NASA GLOBE Clouds and the Zooniverse online platform, gives you the opportunity to identify cloud types, cloud cover and other phenomena captured in GLOBE cloud photographs of the sky! Go to NASA GLOBE CLOUD GAZE and select one of three project options. What do you see? allows you to identify cloud types and other phenomena. Cloud Cover gives you a chance to report how much of the photograph is covered by clouds. Sky Color asks you what is the deepest shade of blue you observe. In addition, you can chat live with NASA GLOBE CLOUD GAZE researchers and other citizen scientists all on the Zooniverse online platform. The resulting detailed information, or metadata, will make it easier for NASA scientists to use the NASA GLOBE Clouds data in multiple ways.
how_to_join: Go to https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/nasaglobe/nasa-globe-cloud-gaze/ and start analyzing sky photographs. You can also create a Zooniverse account and keep track of all your observations. Use the talk option to chat with NASA researchers of the project or other participants.
participation_confirmation_message:
Hello!

Thank you for your interest in NASA GLOBE CLOUD GAZE.

location_type.label: Online only (The entire activity takes place at a computer or on a smart phone)

activities.label: At a science center, zoo or aquarium

special_skills: Love for clouds and sky photographs
data_results: The data will be available to others. The Zooniverse online platform already protects all participants personal information. Only the data will be shared.
data_license:
No license is necessary. Only requirement is citation. 

The data will be made available in 2022 at https://observer.globe.gov/es/get-data/clouds-data

name: Fresh Eyes on Ice
goal: Document river ice conditions all around the world
task: Take photographs of river ice conditions using the GLOBE Observer App
description:
The Fresh Eyes on Ice project is building a network of ice observers to improve public safety on river ice, to support flood forecasting, and to better understand the impacts of climate change. 

You can contribute to this project by sharing your photo observations of river ice conditions using the GLOBE Observer App. Photos of freeze-up, open water leads, ice cover, ice melt, and break-up are all encouraged.
how_to_join:
Follow these steps to participate:
- Download the GLOBE Observer App to your smartphone.
- Select the Land Cover protocol.
- The app will guide you to take photos directly up and directly down.
- The app will guide you to take photos in the four cardinal directions (North, East, South, and West). You will see a digital compass on your screen to help you align your photos. You may only need to take photos in one or two directions to capture the waterbody.
- In the field notes, type "Fresh Eyes on Ice". That will help us retrieve your observations.
- In the field notes, also describe what is pictured in the photographs.
- Click the green button to send your observation to GLOBE. You can do this immediately or wait until later if you do not have internet connectivity.

Thank you for your contributions to science and public safety!

You can visit https://observer.globe.gov to learn more about GLOBE Observer and the Landcover tool. 

Children under the age of 13 should be supervised by an adult when using the app. Always follow guidelines from your local officials, and only participate in GLOBE activities or use the GLOBE Observer app if it is safe to do so.

When you download the app, please use the same email address you used to sign up for a SciStarter account, and use the referral code “scistarter” so all of your contributions will be credited to your SciStarter dashboard!

name: Ghosts of the Coast
goal: Document the formation of ghost forests.
task: Record ghost forest observations through Survey123 form.
description:
The formation of ghost forests in response to sea level rise, land subsidence, and saltwater intrusion is a striking visual indicator of climate change. Ghost forests are characterized by lingering stands of dead trees that were recently killed by salt stress. Ghost forests can form in any type of forest, but the formation of ghost forests in the maritime forests of the Mid-Atlantic sea level rise hotspot has been rapid and conspicuous.

We are engaging citizen scientists to help document the formation of ghost forests at a larger scale. The goal of this initiative is to raise awareness about the pace of change in coastal landscapes, while also collecting data that can inform ghost forest research. 

Help us document ghost forest formation! Your recorded observations will populate a public collaborative ghost forest map as part of a larger ghost forest website.
search_terms: Ghost forest, marsh, sea level rise, Chesapeake Bay, climate change, coastal, coastal ecology, maritime forest, marsh migration, ecology, ghosts of the coast, Maryland, Virginia, Delaware, New Jersey, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, New York, forest, wetlands,  salt water intrusion, coastal marine ecology, salt stress, pine, cedar, spartina patens, dead trees, flood, flooding, storm, disturbance, rising seas, land conversion, swamp, dying trees, sap, phragmites, mid Atlantic, Virginia Coast Reserve, The George Washington University, Gedan Lab, tidal inundation, salt, salt water, coastal education, bleached trees, groundwater, tree death, low elevation, salt tolerant, dying forest, hurricane, changing shoreline, shoreline, stump, tree stump, tide, storymap, survey123, east coast, global warming, killing trees, Keryn Gedan, Delaware Bay, Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge, Blackwater National Refuge, Cattus Island, Delmarva Peninsula, eastern shore, sweet gum, cordgrass, saltwater marshes, saltwater, Somerset county, soil, blue crab, estuary, geology, geography, Mullica river estuary, wood, saline, riverbank, tributaries, seawater, saltwater marsh, salt tolerant plants, sawgrass, black needle rush, drought, changing landscape, wildfires, regeneration, marine
how_to_join:
After or during a visit to a ghost forest visit our survey to record your observation: https://survey123.arcgis.com/share/ba6cc9df90bb4cb896bc0d9484df8ba9

Then visit https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/12863715c76a40d8928e467845801b03 to view your observation on a public collaborative ghost forest map!

name: OpenTEK

promotion_time.label: Prefer promotion on the target date

goal: Document climate change impacts reported by communities and researchers.
task: Reporting observations and research by adding entries in the platform.
description: Local Indicators of Climate Change Impacts (LICCI). The Contribution of Local Knowledge to Climate Change Research – is a project that aims to bring insights from Indigenous and local knowledge to climate research. To do that, LICCI has created the OpenTEK citizen science platform.
search_terms: Climate change, impacts, Indigenous, traditional knowledge, local knowledge ecology, observation, global, nature, climate change impacts, ethnographic fieldstudies, climate research, biodiversity, agrobiodiversity, bioculture, ethnoecology, ethnobiology, cultural believes, spirituality, livelihoods, crops, fisheries, livestock, natural disaster, drought, flood, rainfall changes, increase, decrease
how_to_join: A local observation can be submitted by anyone even without registration. Login with Sci-starter is also possible. The guidelines cover many aspects of the platform: https://hackmd.io/@opentek/overview
materials: Smartphone, tablet or computer. The platform is designed as a progressive web-app (PWA) allowing users with IOS both to visualize existing geolocalized data and to collect new data from any device and while in the field.
special_skills: basic internet skills, using smartphone, tablet or computer.

name: Healthy Beech Project
presenter: Maine Soil and Water Conservation Districts
goal: To collect location and other information on any apparently healthy American beech trees (Fagus grandifolia) growing ...
task: Add location and other information about apparently healthy American beech trees you find.
description: In this project, we are collecting information on any apparently healthy American beech trees (Fagus grandifolia) growing in Maine to help researchers find trees with possible genetic resistance to beech bark scale disease. Possibly resistant beech have smooth, gray trunks free of the holes, scars and cracks found on diseased beech.
